name: Tirshi (Tunisian Pumpkin Salad)
name_origin: Derived from the Arabic word 'turshi' (طرشي), which generally means 'pickles' or 'pickled vegetables' throughout the Middle East and Maghreb. The word ultimately traces back to the Persian 'torsh' (ترش) meaning 'sour' or 'acidic'. In the context of Tunisian and Libyan Jewish cuisine, the meaning shifted from whole pickled vegetables to a specific cooked, mashed salad (usually pumpkin or carrot) that is heavily seasoned with vinegar or lemon juice, garlic, and caraway (karwiya). The name refers to the sour, pungent flavor profile that functions like a pickle to cut through the richness of Shabbat stews or couscous, rather than the texture.
description: A classic Tunisian Jewish cooked salad made from mashed pumpkin, garlic, and spices. It is traditionally served cold or at room temperature as part of the 'kemia' (appetizer spread) on Shabbat and holidays.
cultural_context: A staple of Djerban and Tunisian cuisine. While 'Tirshi' can refer to various pickled vegetables in other Middle Eastern contexts, for Tunisian Jews, it almost exclusively refers to this specific pumpkin dip. It is known for its vibrant orange color and bold flavor profile.

ingredients.name: Pumpkin or Butternut Squash
ingredients.notes: Butternut squash is often preferred for better texture

ingredients.name: Potato
ingredients.notes: Adds creaminess to the final texture

ingredients.name: Vegetable oil
ingredients.notes: Can use neutral oil or light olive oil

ingredients.name: Cumin
ingredients.notes: Can be substituted with caraway for a more traditional Djerban flavor

steps.instruction: Boil the pumpkin cubes (and potato, if using) in water until completely soft and tender.
steps.tips: Test with a fork to ensure they are soft enough to mash easily.

steps.instruction: Drain the vegetables thoroughly. It is important to remove as much water as possible to avoid a watery dip.
steps.tips: Letting them sit in a colander for a few minutes helps.

steps.instruction: Mash the vegetables with a fork while they are still warm.
Add the oil, crushed garlic, paprika, cumin, salt, and lemon juice. Mix well to combine.
steps.tips: Taste and adjust salt or lemon as needed.

steps.instruction: Serve cold or at room temperature.

variants.name: Spicy Tirshi
variants.description: Add harissa or hot paprika for a spicy kick.

variants.name: Caraway Tirshi
variants.description: Many traditional recipes use caraway (karwiya) instead of or in addition to cumin.

name_etymology.notes: The linguistic connection is standard in Judeo-Arabic dialectology. While 'Turshi' is standard Arabic for pickles, the specific pronunciation 'Tirshi' or 'Tershi' in the Maghreb (specifically Tunisia and Libya) refers almost exclusively to this mashed dip. The sour element (vinegar/lemon) is the defining characteristic that links it to the etymological root.

alternative_names.name: Tirshi Qra
alternative_names.notes: 'Qra' (قرع) means pumpkin/gourd; specifies the main ingredient.

alternative_names.name: Chershi
alternative_names.notes: The Tripolitan (Libyan) pronunciation of the same dish, often served with couscous.

alternative_names.name: Salade de Citrouille
alternative_names.notes: Colonial era name often used in French-language Jewish cookbooks.

similar_dishes.name: Chershi / Cershi
similar_dishes.similarity: Almost identical dish made of mashed pumpkin, garlic, and caraway.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Libyan version is often spicier (using pilpelchuma) and sometimes more liquid, used as a sauce for couscous rather than just a salad.

similar_dishes.name: Torshi / Turşu
similar_dishes.key_difference: These are standard vinegar-brined raw vegetables (pickles), whereas Tunisian Tirshi is cooked and mashed.

similar_dishes.name: Zalouk
similar_dishes.similarity: Cooked, mashed vegetable salad served as a dip.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Zalouk is primarily eggplant and tomato based, whereas Tirshi is pumpkin based.

similar_dishes.name: Om Hourieh
similar_dishes.key_difference: Om Hourieh is made from carrots, though a 'Carrot Tirshi' exists which blurs the lines.

intro_paragraph: Tirshi derives from the Arabic word for pickles, referencing the sharp acidity defining this vibrant cooked salad. Made from mashed pumpkin seasoned with garlic and lemon, it transforms sweet squash into a savory dip. This naturally vegan staple of Djerban cuisine is traditionally served cold as part of the Shabbat spread.
